data.text: Simon, the first thing that would help us answer your question is where are you and where do you ride? In general, smart wool is your answer. If you‚Äôre sweaty in the SW when you stop at camp, I suggest an immediate change of clothes. The chamois will stay moist and so will the base layer so change them out when you know you‚Äôre stopping for a while. Hands and feet will be the first to go so good camp socks and gloves that allow for dexterity will be key. Never underestimate the head and neck. If you get cold quickly, on the regular, I suggest a warm packable hat and here in Wisconsin, I never leave the house without a gator or scarf around my neck.

data.text: If you stop for a break during your ride, put on a windproof jacket. If that‚Äôs not enough, add a warm layer under the jacket. Take those off when you start to ride again. Then, when you get to camp, strip off the sweaty layers & give yourself a quick rub down with your tiny camp towel to get rid of any sweat, then put on your dry camp clothing. Hopefully, you‚Äôll have some Sunshine to dry your sweaty layers, but if not, throw them in the bottom of your sleeping bag before the evening dew makes them wetter, & sleep with them in there. I did this for years on winter ski traverses & it kept me warm & dry. Alternately, if you‚Äôre stopped & getting cold, do some calisthenics or jump around a bit to warm up. I don‚Äôt wear merino wool next to my skin because it makes me itchy, & I find it takes longer to dry or wick than synthetics, but its certainly warmer & doesn‚Äôt get stinky the way synthetics do!
